------=_Part_7477_1694223004.1123176635100
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Hi,

I'm trying to model soot formation for an engine cycle with 
exhaust gas recirculation. I've modelled the system in a reactor 
net such that air and exhaust gases are mixed in the mixing 
junction. The outlet of the mixing junction goes into the 
combustor. Combustor feeds its exhaust gases into a flow split, 
which splits the exhaust gases into two streams, one going into 
the mixing junction and the other is exhausted from the tail pipe. 
The ratio of the mass flow rates of the two streams is known as 
the recirculation ratio.

Once I try to advance such a reactor net, the program crashes. I 
need help with figuring out where I'm going wrong.

I've attached my files below. The files also include a sketch of 
the system I'm trying to model.

In addition, there's one thing I do not understand well enough. 
The ignitor is modelled as a reservoir for H atoms. When I ran the 
model for a conventional engine system, as given in the python 
example for continuously stirred reactors, I got temperatures as 
high as 6500 K. I had to  change the H-atoms to CH3 to get the 
temperatures within reasonable limits. Could I be going wrong 
somewhere?
Is there a means of sending a pure temperature pulse rather that 
sending an ignitor_mdot pulse. Besides, wouldn't sending a pulse 
of H atoms alter the reaction chemistry?

Thank you,

Bhupinder

--
Bhupinder Singh
Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering
University of Florida
Gainesville

Ph: 352-392-4442 (O)
